ticket.title: [PATCH] Add a NullStore to ActiveSupport::Cache
ticket.original-body:
With the config `action_controller.perform_caching = false`, action controller still tries to use the cache_store to perform Rails.cache.- style caching. This is surprising behavior.
Either:
1. The config setting should be renamed to be clear about what you are controlling, or preferably, 2. Rails.cache.read should return nil when perform_caching is false. cache.read returning nil should already be handled by the application.
There is already a protected "convenience accessor" (Cache#cache) that uses cache_configured? to give this (2) actual behavior, yielding the block when caching is not set up.
Tickets #639, #785, and #1290 all dance around this issue -- #639 is marked 'invalid', and #785 and #1290 are marked as dupes of #1339. In development, *being able to actually turn off caching* while leaving `cache_classes = false` would solve many of these issues for common use scenarios.

With the config `action_controller.perform_caching = false`, action controller still tries to use the cache_store to perform Rails.cache.- style caching. This is surprising behavior.
Either:
1. The config setting should be renamed to be clear about what you are controlling, or preferably, 2. Rails.cache.read should return nil when perform_caching is false. cache.read returning nil should already be handled by the application.
There is already a protected "convenience accessor" (Cache#cache) that uses cache_configured? to give this (2) actual behavior, yielding the block when caching is not set up.
Tickets #639, #785, and #1290 all dance around this issue -- #639 is marked 'invalid', and #785 and #1290 are marked as dupes of #1339. In development, *being able to actually turn off caching* while leaving `cache_classes = false` would solve many of these issues for common use scenarios.

With the config action_controller.perform_caching = false, action controller still tries to use the cache_store to perform Rails.cache.- style caching. This is surprising behavior.

Either:

  1. The config setting should be renamed to be clear about what you are controlling, or preferably,
  2. Rails.cache.read should return nil when perform_caching is false. cache.read returning nil should already be handled by the application.

There is already a protected "convenience accessor" (Cache#cache) that uses cache_configured? to give this (2) actual behavior, yielding the block when caching is not set up.

Tickets #639, #785, and #1290 all dance around this issue -- #639 is marked 'invalid', and #785 and #1290 are marked as dupes of #1339. In development, being able to actually turn off caching while leaving cache_classes = false would solve many of these issues for common use scenarios.

With the config `action_controller.perform_caching = false`, action controller still tries to use the cache_store to perform Rails.cache.- style caching. This is surprising behavior.
Either:
1. The config setting should be renamed to be clear about what you are controlling, or preferably, 2. Rails.cache.read should return nil when perform_caching is false. cache.read returning nil should already be handled by the application.
There is already a protected "convenience accessor" (Cache#cache) that uses cache_configured? to give this (2) actual behavior, yielding the block when caching is not set up.
Tickets #639, #785, and #1290 all dance around this issue -- #639 is marked 'invalid', and #785 and #1290 are marked as dupes of #1339. In development, *being able to actually turn off caching* while leaving `cache_classes = false` would solve many of these issues for common use scenarios.
version.body-html:
With the config action_controller.perform_caching = false, action controller still tries to use the cache_store to perform Rails.cache.- style caching. This is surprising behavior.

Either:

  1. The config setting should be renamed to be clear about what you are controlling, or preferably,
  2. Rails.cache.read should return nil when perform_caching is false. cache.read returning nil should already be handled by the application.

There is already a protected "convenience accessor" (Cache#cache) that uses cache_configured? to give this (2) actual behavior, yielding the block when caching is not set up.

Tickets #639, #785, and #1290 all dance around this issue -- #639 is marked 'invalid', and #785 and #1290 are marked as dupes of #1339. In development, being able to actually turn off caching while leaving cache_classes = false would solve many of these issues for common use scenarios.
version.title: Perform caching=false should not perform caching

version.body: I just spend 30 minutes trying to figure this out too, when starting to use Rails.cache. If no one is working on this I'll write a patch - looks pretty simple.
version.body-html: I just spend 30 minutes trying to figure this out too, when starting to use Rails.cache. If no one is working on this I'll write a patch - looks pretty simple.
version.title: Perform caching=false should not perform caching
Perform caching=false should not perform caching

version.body:
Since the Rails.cache functionality exists in ActiveSupport and not ActionController, I propose a new configuration setting of config.active_support.perform_caching= with a default of true.
The patch adds this behavior to Active Support and also modifies the stores to honor the setting. exists? and read will return false and nil respectively when perform caching is set to false. Feedback?
version.body-html:
Since the Rails.cache functionality exists in ActiveSupport and not ActionController, I propose a new configuration setting of config.active_support.perform_caching= with a default of true.

The patch adds this behavior to Active Support and also modifies the stores to honor the setting. exists? and read will return false and nil respectively when perform caching is set to false. Feedback?
version.title: Perform caching=false should not perform caching

version.diffable-attributes: --- :tag: bugmash :title: Perform caching=false should not perform caching
version.title: [PATCH] Perform caching=false should not perform caching

version.body:
+1, this seems like an appropriate change. Shouldn't break backwards compatibility.
Applies cleanly to latest master & tests pass.
version.body-html:
+1, this seems like an appropriate change. Shouldn't break backwards compatibility.

Applies cleanly to latest master & tests pass.
version.title: [PATCH] Perform caching=false should not perform caching

version.body: Ok, now I get that when you say "action_controller.perform_caching = false", you're turning off page, action, and fragment caching, not all caching that happens in your controllers. Somehow that was not clear to me. But, +1 on John's patch -- there should be some way to also turn off ActiveSupport caching, and the patch does that ably. One thing I would change for cleanliness -- I'd set @@perform_caching=true first, which seems to be common practice in Rails. The section where @@perform_caching is checked for nil seemed a little opaque: def self.cache_configured? perform_caching.nil? ? true : perform_caching end I'd add this, and then you don't need to check for nil in #cache_configured?, just return perform_caching: + @@perform_caching = true cattr_accessor :perform_caching I tried to make a new patch but it seemed to add my patch onto John's patch. If there's a cleaner way to to that someone should probably go ahead and do it.
version.body-html:
Ok, now I get that when you say "action_controller.perform_caching = false", you're turning off page, action, and fragment caching, not all caching that happens in your controllers. Somehow that was not clear to me.

But, +1 on John's patch -- there should be some way to also turn off ActiveSupport caching, and the patch does that ably.

One thing I would change for cleanliness -- I'd set @@perform_caching=true first, which seems to be common practice in Rails. The section where @@perform_caching is checked for nil seemed a little opaque:


{mkd-extraction-e508fd6e2a88aa82336506488855005a}

I'd add this, and then you don't need to check for nil in #cache_configured?, just return perform_caching:

+ @@perform_caching = true

{mkd-extraction-d4304b7970b636c816dabf43df1f88e0}

I tried to make a new patch but it seemed to add my patch onto John's patch. If there's a cleaner way to to that someone should probably go ahead and do it.
version.diffable-attributes: --- :title: "[PATCH] Perform caching=false should not perform caching"
version.title: [PATCH] ActiveSupport should have a "perform_caching=false" setting

version.body: Good feedback - thanks, David. Attached is a patch with your feedback that will apply to master.
version.body-html: Good feedback - thanks, David. Attached is a patch with your feedback that will apply to master.
version.title: [PATCH] ActiveSupport should have a "perform_caching=false" setting

version.body: For good measure, here's a patch for 2.3 stable if it's desired to get this in prior to 3.0
version.body-html: For good measure, here's a patch for 2.3 stable if it's desired to get this in prior to 3.0
version.title: [PATCH] ActiveSupport should have a "perform_caching=false" setting

version.body: Talked to nzkoz who was of the opinion that this patch should instead be a null store that users could implement for edge cases in debugging and testing. This makes sense and is more flexible than a configuration setting. Attached is a patch to add a null store to master.
version.body-html: Talked to nzkoz who was of the opinion that this patch should instead be a null store that users could implement for edge cases in debugging and testing. This makes sense and is more flexible than a configuration setting. Attached is a patch to add a null store to master.
version.title: [PATCH] Add a NullStore to ActiveSupport::Cache

version.body: +1 verified and nailed :) Looks like it's a well respected behavior, latest patch applies cleanly on latest master.
version.body-html: +1 verified and nailed :) Looks like it's a well respected behavior, latest patch applies cleanly on latest master.
version.title: [PATCH] Add a NullStore to ActiveSupport::Cache

version.body: What about "BlackholeStore" instead? It's so much more poetic. (There's some reason we're not python developers, right?)
version.body-html: What about "BlackholeStore" instead? It's so much more poetic. (There's some reason we're not python developers, right?)

version.body:
I've rebased the above patch, cleaned up some whitespace issues and updated it slightly so overrides the correct methods (they seem to have changed slightly from when this patch was submitted).
The original authorship has been retained in the patch.
+1 verified

The original authorship has been retained in the patch.

version.title: [PATCH] Add a NullStore to ActiveSupport::Cache

version.body:
I like this patch as it enabled global disabling of the cache. To me it would make sense to have an enabled attribute on the Rails.cache object, something I achieved with a monkey patch:
http://developer.newsdesk.se/2010/05/04/enablingdisabling-the-rails-cache/
version.body-html:
I like this patch as it enabled global disabling of the cache. To me it would make sense to have an enabled attribute on the Rails.cache object, something I achieved with a monkey patch:

http://developer.newsdesk.se/2010/05/04/enablingdisabling-the-rails...
version.title: [PATCH] Add a NullStore to ActiveSupport::Cache

version.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.
The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
version.body-html:

This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.

Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
